rsbNotes.title: Matt 8–9
rsbNotes.text: 8:1–9:38 The order of the miracles and events in these chapters differs from that found in Mark and Luke. Probably Matthew arranged them according to topic rather than chronology.

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:18–25
rsbNotes.text: 9:18–25 As usual, Matthew has a more condensed form of this story than Mark and Luke. Both the story of the ruler’s daughter and the story of the woman with a hemorrhage illustrate the relation between the work of Jesus and the role of faith in the kingdom. The same point appears in the following accounts of the blind man and the mute demoniac. These works (raising the dead, healing the sick, etc.) are in response to faith, not because faith causes them, but because without faith in the King Himself they are not signs of the kingdom but only unaccountable events with no special meaning.

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:22
rsbNotes.text: 9:22 your faith has made you well. Her faith made her well because the blessings of the kingdom come to those who look to Jesus for the solution to their problems, not because of any power of faith in itself.

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:23
rsbNotes.text: 9:23 flute players and the crowd. Professional mourners and others who helped the bereaved express their grief.

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:24
rsbNotes.text: 9:24 not dead but sleeping. Jesus was prophesying that He would raise her up from death (John 11:11–14).

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:27–31
rsbNotes.text: 9:27–31 The healing of two blind men related here is similar to the account in 20:29–34, as well as to the healing of Bartimaeus narrated in Mark 10:46–52 (cf. Luke 18:35–43). Both Bartimaeus and the blind men in Matthew 9 and 20 express their faith by calling Jesus “Son of David,” a messianic title. The similarities have suggested to some that both accounts in Matthew are based on the healing of Bartimaeus, but there are sufficient differences at least between the two accounts in Matthew as to indicate separate incidents.

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:35–38
rsbNotes.text: 9:35–38 This paragraph summarizes the activity of Jesus in chs. 5–9 (teaching, preaching, healing) and introduces the mission discourse of ch. 10. The background is Ezek. 34:5, 6. Jesus is the true Shepherd who is concerned for His sheep (John 10), and He is identified with the “Lord God” of Ezek. 34:11–16.

rsbNotes.title: Matt 9:37
rsbNotes.text: 9:37 harvest. Often a metaphor for the end-time activity of God. That the harvest is “plentiful” indicates that the “harvest” is not the harvest time but the crop (as in Luke 10:2). The emphasis here is on the proclamation of the gospel, the eschatological announcement that precedes judgment and urges people to repent and have faith. The “laborers” are not the angels sent to gather for judgment (13:49) but disciples who imitate Jesus by proclaiming the coming of the kingdom (10:7). Jesus does not yet command His disciples to go into the harvest as laborers, but to pray to God to send workers. No one can do the work of harvest without being called to it and equipped for it by God.
